Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Effect of Reverse Bevel Nasotracheal Intubation on Epistaxis

Trial_Design.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, 74 patients undergoing right-sided maxillofacial surgery requiring left nasotracheal intubation were enrolled

Participants.evidence: 74 patients undergoing right-sided maxillofacial surgery requiring left nasotracheal intubation were enrolled at Asan Medical Center, Seoul, Korea

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly allocated to the control group (conventional tube direction) or the reverse group (180˚ reverse bevel direction)

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the effect of a 180˚ reverse bevel and tip direction of the nasotracheal tube on the incidence of epistaxis during left nostril intubation.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of epistaxis, assessed via videolaryngoscopy.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using web-based software, with allocation concealment ensured.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 74 patients undergoing right-sided maxillofacial surgery requiring left nasotracheal intubation were enrolled at Asan Medical Center, Seoul, Korea, between November 2021 and September 2023.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The incidence of epistaxis was significantly lower in the reverse group (9/37 [24.3%]) compared to the control group (20/37 [54.1%], P = 0.009; relative risk: 0.45, 95% CI [0.24, 0.85]).

Result_Outcome.evidence: The incidence of epistaxis was significantly lower in the reverse group (9/37 [24.3%]) compared to the control group (20/37 [54.1%], P = 0.009; relative risk: 0.45, 95% CI [0.24, 0.85]).

Harms.evidence: No nasotracheal tube-related complications were reported in either group.
